metadata.title: Microwave-assisted Synthesis of Hierarchical Mesoporous Nano-TiO2/Cellu- lose Composites for Rapid Adsorption of Pb2+

Microwave-assisted Synthesis of Hierarchical 1 Mesoporous Nano-TiO2/Cellulose Composites 2
for Rapid Adsorption of Pb 2+ 3
Jinju Zhang a, b, c , Lei Li a, b , Yanxiang Li a, b, *, and Chuanfang Yang a, b, * 4
a State Key Laboratory of Biochemical Engineering, Institute of Process Engineering, 5
Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, China 6

(Y. Li), cfyang@ipe.ac.cn (C. Yang).13
Abstract 1
Cellulose fibers were used as substrates to induce the formation of nano-TiO2 via 2 heterogeneous titanium oxysulfate hydrolysis under microwave irradiation. The 3
microwave provided fast heating for the one-pot reaction at 90 ºC and contributed to the 4
generation of 10 nm anatase TiO2 nanoparticles. These spherical particles further fused 5 into 100 nm raspberry-like mesoporous TiO2 agglomerates uniformly distributed on the 6 cellulose surface. The composite material was able to adsorb Pb2+ very rapidly from 7
simulated wastewater with a maximum capacity of 42.5 mg/g. The adsorption, 8
characterized by pseudo-second order kinetics and Freundlich isotherm, was attributed to 9
the reaction between the hydroxyl groups of TiO2 and Pb 2+ to form Pb-O bond, as 10 indicated by XPS analysis. The adsorbent can be easily regenerated for a number of times 11
without significant reduction in adsorption performances. 12
Key words: cellulose, mesoporous nano-TiO2, microwave-irradiation, hierarchical 13 structured composite, lead adsorption 14 15

sections.heading: 1. Introduction 1
sections.text:
Toxic heavy metal ions in water can cause serious environmental and health issues 2
due to their non-biodegradability and bioaccumulation. Many reliable treatment 3
techniques including adsorption [1-4], chemical precipitation [5], ion-exchange [6, 7], 4
reverse osmosis [8], other membrane technologies [9] and biological treatment [10], as 5
well, have been applied to remove these hazardous metals with varying degrees of success. 6
Among them, adsorption attracts special interest due to its low cost, high flexibility and 7
efficiency, especially for the removal of trace amounts of toxic heavy metal pollutants 8
[11]. 9
Therefore, a great deal of effort was made to develop high efficiency adsorbents such 10
as activated carbon, quartz sand, bentonite, zeolite and oxide materials, for the removal of 11
heavy metal ions in recent years [12]. Nanostructured adsorbents, owning to their high 12
specific surface area and increased active adsorption sites, have been in the center of 13
focus as an emerging water decontamination technology [13]. TiO2 nanoparticles, for 14 example, in addition to their wide applications in various areas due to their excellent 15
physical and chemical properties [14], have been investigated recently as nanosorbents for 16
removing heavy metals [15]. Unfortunately, the use of nanoscale particles in water 17
treatment exhibits some hindrances, which include agglomeration-induced loss of surface 18
area, difficulty of recovery and regeneration, and environment risks caused by the 19
lapsed-particles [16]. Therefore, researchers have tended to prepare hybrid 20
nanocomposites by immobilizing nanoparticles onto large solid substrates, which can still 21
offer high specific surface area and enhanced adsorption performance with a realized cost 1
[17]. 2
Cellulose used as a hydrophilic substrate to fabricate hybrid nanocomposites has been 3
reported due to its natural characteristics and renewable origins [18-20]. The 4
multi-hydroxyl functionalities on the surface of cellulose can offer many active sites to 5
promote the nucleation and growth of inorganic oxides, which could prevent the 6
agglomeration of nanoparticles if controlled purposely, and subsequently ensures a high 7
specific-surface area. Consequently, various synthetic routes have been developed to 8
immobile nano-TiO2 onto cellulose matrix, such as sol-gel [21], hydrothermal [22], layer 9 by layer (LBL) [23] assembly and hydrolysis treatment [24]. Hydrothermal and 10
hydrolysis methods typically require heating to attain certain temperature for the reaction 11
to take place. Conventional heating approach is time consuming, microwave irradiation is 12
therefore developed to provide rapid heating rates, and as a plus, molecular homogeneity, 13
improved reaction kinetics and fast crystallization as well, thus leading to the 14
simplification of materials preparation procedure [25-27]. 15
In this study, we utilized a facile microwave-assisted hydrolysis method to synthesize 16
TiO2/cellulose composites, and obtained raspberry-like TiO2 nanoparticles distributed 17 uniformly on the cellulose fiber surface, which in turn offered high surface area and 18
contributed to rapid adsorption performance. This method was characterized with 19
inexpensive raw materials, rapid reaction at relatively low temperature and atmospheric 20
pressure, and good repeatability. The as-prepared composite fibers were used to remove 21
Pb2+ from water by stirred-tank batch adsorption and further made into fibrous membrane 1 bed to adsorb Pb2+ dynamically. The adsorption kinetics, thermodynamics, material 2
regeneration, as well as adsorption mechanism were studied in detail. 3

sections.heading: 2.1 Materials and reagents 5
sections.text:
Titanium (IV) oxysulfate solution (TiOSO4, ~15wt % in dilute sulfuric acid, 99.99% 6 trace metals basis) used as the titanium source was purchased from Aldrich. Sulfuric acid 7
(H2SO4) was purchased from Beijing Chemical Works, China. Lead (II) nitrate (Pb(NO3)2) 8 used as the model pollutant was purchased from Beijing Chemical Works, China. 9
Cellulose fibers (UF 500) (Tensile strength > 750 MPa) with diameter of 10~30 µm were 10
purchased from Beijing Ronel Engineering Materials Co. Ltd., and washed with distilled 11
water before use. All the chemicals were of analytical grade and used without further 12
purification. 13

sections.heading: 2.2 Synthesis of TiO2/cellulose fiber (TiO2/CF) composite 14
sections.text:
A facile microwave-assisted hydrolysis method was used to synthesize the TiO2/CF 15 composites. Initially, 1.0 g of cellulose fibers was added to a mixture of distilled water 16
(150.0 mL) and sulphuric acid (1.0 mL) in a round bottom flask under constant stirring. 17
The flask was then placed in an automatically controlled microwave reactor (Yuhua, 18
MCR-3 750 W) and pre-heated to 90 ºC by microwave radiation with an output power of 19
400 W under atmospheric pressure. Then 0.6 mL of TiOSO4 was added to the flask, and 1 microwave irradiation was applied again for different times to speed up the hydrolysis. 2
After the reaction, the formed TiO2/CF composite fibers were collected and processed by 3 filtering, thorough washing with distilled water and drying at 50 ºC under vacuum for 12 4
h. 5

sections.heading: 2.3 Lead adsorption 6
sections.text:
Lead ion adsorption experiments were performed by a stirred-tank batch method. 7 Lead nitrate was used to prepare the simulated wastewater with different Pb2+ 8
concentration. In order to compare the results with the previous research [28], the initial 9 Pb2+ concentration of 35 mg/L was chosen to investigate the materials in detail. The 10 adsorption kinetics and isotherm were studied by changing the initial Pb2+ concentration, 11
pH and adsorption time. The initial pH values of the solutions were adjusted by 0.01 M 12
HNO3 and 0.01 M NaOH. 13 In a typical adsorption procedure, 0.024 g TiO2/CF composite fibers as the adsorbents 14 were put into 60 mL Pb2+-containing solution in a capped bottle. The mixture was then 15
placed on a platform shaker operating at 150 rpm (25 ºC) until the adsorption reached 16 equilibrium. After the adsorption, the Pb2+ solution was separated from the adsorbent by a 17
0.22 µm nylon syringe filter. The supernatant was collected and analyzed to determine the 18
remaining lead concentration. 19 The adsorption capacity Q (mg/g) of Pb2+ on the TiO2/CF fibers was calculated using 20 Equation (1). 21
0 e
Q = (C - C )V / M (1) 1
where C0 (mg/L) and Ce (mg/L) are the initial and equilibrium concentrations of Pb 2+, 2 respectively; V (mL) is the volume of the solution and M (g) the mass of the adsorbent. 3

sections.heading: 2.4 Characterization 4
sections.text:
The morphology and structure of the prepared samples were investigated by using 5
field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, JSM-6700F, Japan), transmission 6
electron microscope (TEM, JEM-2100F, Japan), high-resolution transmission electron 7
microscopy (HRTEM, JEM-2100F, Japan) and selected area electron diffraction pattern 8
(SAED, JEM-2100F, Japan). To prepare the TEM samples, 50 mg of TiO2/CF composite 9 were dispersed in 60 mL ethanol followed by vigorous stirring for 24 h, and then 1 µL of 10
the suspension was dropped onto a carbon-coated copper grid and dried in air. The crystal 11
phase was characterized with X-ray diffraction (XRD, Smartlab, Japan) using Cu Kα 12
irradiation, operated at 45 kV and 200 mA with a scanning rate of 5 °/min. Thermal 13
properties were examined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, TG-DTA6300, Japan) 14
with air as the carrier gas at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Specific surface area of the 15
composite samples was measured at liquid nitrogen temperature (77 K) using 16
Brunauer-Emmett-Teller method (BET, Autosorb-IQ-MP, America). Zeta potential of the 17
composite fibers was analyzed using Malvern Zetasizer Nano Series (Zetasizer, Nano ZS, 18
England). Surface information of the samples was detected by X-ray photoelectron 19
spectrophotometer (XPS, ESCALAB 250Xi, America). The binding energy scale for final 20
calibration was corrected by the C1s peak corresponding to 284.8 eV. The lead ion 1
concentration was measured using atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS, Hitachi 2000, 2
Japan). An inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Thermo 3
Scientific) was used to measure the concentration of Ti element in solutions at wavelength 4
of 334.94 nm. 5

sections.heading: 3.1 Characterization of the TiO2/cellulose composite/hybrid fibers 7
sections.text:
TiO2/cellulose nanocomposites were prepared by one-pot TiOSO4 hydrolysis in the 8 presence of microwave irradiation. The preparation process is illustrated in Scheme 1. 9
Briefly, when the precursor salt was mixed with cellulose fibers at a preset-temperature 10
under microwave irradiation, the abundant polar groups on the surface of cellulose acted 11 as microwave absorbents. In the acidic solution environment, they also adsorb Ti4+ as the 12
precursor by electrostatic interaction for the heterogeneous hydrolysis to start on cellulose 13
surface. TiO2 nanocrystals were then quickly formed in situ on the surface. In essence, the 14 abundant oxygen-containing functional groups of cellulose interacted with the hydroxyl 15
groups of Ti(OH)4 nuclei to form the initial TiO2 nanoparticles [29] Compared with 16 traditional convective heating, the introduced microwave irradiation provided rapid 17
decomposition of the precursor and promoted TiO2 nucleation and crystallization [30]. 18 The microwave irradiation greatly shortened the reaction time from a few hours using 19
convection heating to only minutes in the current work [28]. 20
The field emission SEM images in Fig. 1 are the morphology of the cellulose fibers 1
before and after immobilization of TiO2. Fig. 1a is ascribed to the surface of pure 2 cellulose fibers before attachment of any nanoparticles. It is smooth and characterized 3
with the presence of many microfibers. Fig. 1(b-d) shows the surfaces of cellulose fibers 4
doped with TiO2 nanoparticles after microwave-assisted hydrolysis reaction for different 5 times. With increased irradiation time, the amount and the size of TiO2 nanoparticles both 6 increase. When the irradiation time is 15 min (Fig. 1c), TiO2 particles of 100 nm 7 uniformly distribute on cellulose, forming a rough surface, the produced TiO2/CF fibers 8 are 10~30 µm in diameter and 2~3 mm in length. However, when zoomed in, we found 9
that these particles are agglomerates of 10 nm primary TiO2 nanoparticles as demonstrated 10 by the inset of Fig. 1c. The formation of such a structure maybe attributed to the special 11
non-thermal effect of microwave irradiation. The other role of the cellulose fibers 12
(diameter 10~30 µm) is to control the aggregation of nano-TiO2 particles by taking 13 advantage of the abundant hydroxyl groups of cellulose to lock the particles down once 14
they are formed. As reported, the hydroxyl groups have a tendency to promote the 15
heterogeneous nucleation and growth of inorganic materials in situ in an aqueous medium 16
[30-32]. Once the small nanocrystals are formed, in given time, secondary nucleation will 17
occur on the existing crystals and consume the precursor quickly to form separate crystals. 18
These crystals then come together in turn to form the raspberry-like structure with 19
mesopores, as will be discussed again later with TEM analysis. 20
The amount of immobilized TiO2 nanoparticles is also reaction time dependent as 1 proved by TGA analysis in Fig. 2a. The TiO2/CF composites experience three weight loss 2 stages. The first stage below 100 ºC is attributed to the loss of physically adsorbed water 3
and solvents [33]. The second stage between 250 ºC and 350 ºC is assigned to the partial 4
decomposition of the cellulose fibers [34, 35]. The weight loss of pure cellulose has the 5
same first stage but different second stage curve, where the starting point of fiber 6
decomposition is about 50 ºC later. The reason may be that the cellulose fibers exposed to 7
the hydrolysis reaction conditions might have been altered chemically to some extent so 8
they start to discompose at a lower temperature. The third stage between 450 ºC and 500 9
ºC indicates the complete decomposition of cellulose [36]. Based on the TG result, the 10
amount of TiO2 in the composites prepared at reaction time of 2, 15 and 30 min were 11 determined to be 2.1%, 4.7% and 8.4%, respectively, corresponding to the trend shown in 12
the SEM images in Fig. 1. The specific surface area of the TiO2/CF composites fabricated 13 at different reaction times is provided in Table 1, where it can be seen that as the TiO2 14 content is increased, the area also increases. Those of TiO2/CF-2 min, TiO2/CF-15 min 15 and TiO2/CF-30 min are 5.34 m 2/g, 14.95 m2/g and 17.82 m2/g, respectively. The nitrogen 16 adsorption-desorption isotherm of TiO2/CF-15 min is shown in Fig. 2b. This composite’s 17 specific surface area (14.95 m2/g) is 21 times higher than pure cellulose. The shape of the 18
adsorption-desorption curves represents a typical type IV isotherm, indicating the 19
presence of mesopores [37, 38]. 20
The microstructure of the prepared composite was further revealed by TEM and 1
HRTEM images in Fig. 3. As implied in the TEM image, some microfibers (500~600 nm) 2
can disintegrate from the big (10~30 µm) flat cellulose fibers due to strong magnetic 3
stirring, nonetheless, it was noticed that the TiO2 nanoparticles distributed uniformly on 4 the surface of these fibers (Fig. 3a). The enlarged TEM (inset of Fig. 3a), shows that these 5
particles, averaged ~100 nm in diameter, are agglomerates of 10 nm spherical primary 6
TiO2 nanoparticles, as already indicated in the SEM image of the inset of Fig. 1c. 7 However, with the TEM analysis, it is clearly seen that these agglomerates are porous in 8
nature and have mesoporous structure due to the geometric piling up of TiO2 primary 9 nanoparticles, as also discussed and confirmed in reference to Fig. 2b. The HR-TEM 10
micrograph of Fig. 3b shows clear lattice spacing, which is ascribed to the (101) plane of 11
anatase TiO2 with the corresponding fringe distance of 0.352 nm [39]. The selected area 12 electron diffraction (SAED) image in the inset of Fig. 3b shows the diffraction ring 13
patterns, confirming the polycrystalline nature of the anatase phase of TiO2. 14 Fig. 3c shows the XRD patterns of pure cellulose and TiO2/CF composites prepared 15 with the reaction time of 15 min. The intensive diffraction peak at 2θ = 22.9° is ascribed 16
to the (002) plane of cellulose, and the characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ = 25.28°, 17
37.80° and 48.05° correspond to the (101), (004) and (200) crystal planes of anatase phase 18
of titania [40], respectively. After the microwave-assisted hydrolysis reaction at 90 ºC, the 19
obtained nano-TiO2 particles were successfully immobilized on the surface of cellulose 20 fibers and exhibited a single anatase phase. It is worthy to mention that the characteristic 21
peaks of TiO2 are weaker than those of cellulose. This is attributed to the fact that the 1 fractional amount of TiO2 is very low compared with the major component of cellulose in 2 the composite. 3
The binding strength of TiO2 particles to the cellulose fibers is an important factor to 4 evaluate for the composite materials’ real applications. Here we took a practical approach 5
by using ultrasonication to challenge the composite fibers and determine if TiO2 6 nanoparticles could be shaken off from the cellulose fibers. To do so, the composites of 7
TiO2/CF-15min were dispersed in 50 mL distilled water under continuously sonication for 8 10 min. The solid fibers were then removed by a 0.22 µm nylon syringe filter and the 9
possible existence of Ti element in the filtered solution was checked on ICP-OES. The 10
result showed no detection of Ti in the filtered solution. This is indicative that the TiO2 11 nanoparticles were firmly immobilized onto the surface of cellulose because of the 12
chemical bonds formed between the hydroxyl groups of cellulose and TiO2. 13
3.2 Pb 2+ adsorption experiments 14
The adsorption performance was investigated mainly for TiO2/CF-15 min. All the 15 batch adsorption experiments were carried out at 25 ºC using the platform shaker running 16
at 150 rpm. Dynamic adsorption experiments using filter bed were also conducted as will 17
be discussed later in Section 3.2.2. 18
3.2.1 Effect of pH 19
pH of the initial solution is an important controlling factor for the adsorption of Pb2+ 1 on the TiO2/CF composite. The initial concentration of Pb 2+ was fixed at 35 mg/L and the 2 adsorbent dose was 0.4 g/L. Fig. 4a shows the influence of pH ranging from 2.0 to 6.0. 3
The adsorption capacity increases almost linearly with the increase of pH. Such a strong 4
dependency is related to the surface charge of the composite. As can be seen from the zeta 5
potential test result shown in Fig. 4b, the isoelectric point of the TiO2/CF composite is 6 5.48. When the pH is below 5.48, the surface of the composite comprised of mainly TiO2 7 particles is charged positively; otherwise it is charged negatively. Therefore, when pH > 8 5.48, the negatively charged surface of TiO2 would adsorb Pb 2+ strongly owing to the 9 electrostatic attraction; contrarily, when pH < 5.48, the adsorption becomes weaker as the 10 pH reduced due to the more positively charged surface that repels Pb2+ more intensively. 11
However, the adsorption still happens, meaning other adsorption mechanisms must exist 12
when the pH is below the isoelectric point [41]. For the focus of this work, we chose the 13 initial pH of 6 to further study Pb2+ adsorption instead. 14

sections.heading: 3.2.2 Adsorption kinetics 15
sections.text:
Fig. 5a shows the amount of adsorption as a function of contact time at pH 6.0, with 16 the initial Pb2+ concentration varying from 5 mg/L to 100 mg/L. Clearly, the adsorption 17
happens really quickly in the first 5 min, reaching 55-81% of the equilibrium/saturated 18 adsorption capacity depending on the initial Pb2+ concentration. All the adsorption 19
equilibrium was delivered within 60 min, and the equilibrium capacity increases with the 20 increase of initial Pb2+ concentration. The fast adsorption at the beginning is attributed to 21
the relatively high specific surface area of the composite that offers many freshly 1 available active sites and the high concentration gradient of Pb2+ from the bulk solution to 2
the fiber surface that facilitates mass transfer. After that, the adsorption becomes slower 3 due to the increased number of occupied adsorption sites and the slower diffusion of Pb2+ 4
from TiO2 surface to its inner side [42]. 5 The experimental data were fitted with pseudo-second order kinetic model with high 6 correlation coefficient of R2 > 0.996 as shown in Fig. 5b and Table 2, suggesting the 7
adsorption is dominated by chemisorption, which involves sharing or exchange of 8 electrons between Pb2+ and TiO2/CF composites [43]. The pseudo-second order model is 9
expressed as follows: 10

where Qe (mg/g) and Qt (mg/g) are the amounts of adsorption at equilibrium and any time 12 t, respectively, k is the rate constant (g/mg·min). 13
In order to investigate the adsorption performance of different adsorbents synthesized 14
over different times, the adsorption experiments were also carried out under the same 15
conditions, and the results are shown in Fig. 5c. It shows that with the increase of reaction 16
time, the adsorption capacity also increases. The adsorption capacity of TiO2/CF-30 min is 17 14 % higher than that of TiO2/CF-15 min, although the former composite has 79 % more 18 TiO2 than the latter. The adsorption data are all fitted well with pseudo-second order 19
kinetic model as can be seen in Fig. 5d. Other data comparison including detailed 1
adsorption capacity, specific surface area and isoelectric point can be found in Table 1. 2
Fig. 6a shows the adsorption curve for pure cellulose fibers whose saturated capacity 3
is 0.56 mg/g only, which is negligible compared with 17.5 mg/g for the TiO2/CF-15 min 4 plotted in the same figure under the same experimental conditions. In addition, the 5
adsorption capacity of TiO2/CF-4.5 h prepared by using conventional heating, which was 6 reported earlier in another research [28], is 1.5 times lower than the composite of 7
TiO2/CF-15 min in this work, showing the advantage of the current material. 8 For further comparison, the synthesized composite fibers were made into a fibrous 9
membrane bed using simple vacuum filtration for dynamic adsorption, following the 10
procedure described in our previous research [44]. The membrane beds prepared have the 11 same basis weight (5.76 g/m2), geometric dimension (diameter 47 mm, thickness 1.5 mm) 12
and the same TiO2 content, while the difference is the heating methods for generating the 13 composite fibers. We found that the performance of the current bed is much better than 14
the one reported earlier. The data are shown in Fig. 6b. The loading capacity (in terms of 15
bed volume) of the bed made from the current composite of TiO2/CF-15 min by 16 microwave irradiation is 2.4 times that of the bed made from of the composite fibers of 17
TiO2/CF-7 h through conventional heating. 18

sections.heading: 3.2.3 Adsorption isotherms 19
sections.text:
The equilibrium adsorption data in Fig. 7 were used to determine the adsorption 20
isotherm, where both Langmuir and Freundlich isotherm models were tested to simulate 21
the thermodynamic process, respectively. Langmuir isotherm assumes the adsorption sites 1
of the adsorbent are well-distributed to accomplish a monomolecular layer adsorption [45]. 2
It can be written as Equation (3): 3

Freundlich isotherm is an empirical relationship applicable to describe homogeneous and 8
heterogeneous surfaces, and applied to multilayer adsorption [46]. The model is expressed 9
as follows: 10

n e f eQ = K C (4) 11
where Qe (mg/g) is the equilibrium adsorption capacity, Ce (mg/L) is the equilibrium 12 concentration, n and Kf are the Freundlich constants. 13 The Langmuir and Freundlich isotherm fitting curves with the experimental data in 14
solid square are shown in Fig. 7. The corresponding fitting parameters are listed in Table 3. 15 The data were fitted with Freundlich model better than Langmuir model (R2 of 0.996 vs. 16
0.952), indicating multi-layer adsorption should have occurred on the surface of TiO2/CF 17 composite, which is not unexpected due to the inhomogeneous rough surface structure of 18
the composite. 19

sections.heading: 3.2.4 Adsorption mechanism 1
sections.text:
The adsorption of Pb2+ to the mesoporous TiO2 anchored on the surface of cellulose 2 fibers is dependent on the nature of active adsorption sites of the adsorbent. To help 3 understand the adsorption mechanism, XPS analysis of TiO2/CF before and after Pb 2+ 4 adsorption was conducted. Fig. 8a clearly shows the existence of Ti 2p peak indicating the 5
presence of TiO2. The appearance of Pb 4f peak of the used composite confirms the 6 adsorption of Pb2+. Comparatively, the Pb 4f spectra of pure Pb(NO3)2 and the adsorbed 7 Pb2+ on the TiO2/CF composites are shown in Fig. 8b. It is apparent that for Pb(NO3)2 the 8 spectra are centered at 144.3 eV for 4f5/2 and 139.4 eV for 4f7/2, respectively, while for 9 Pb-composite, an obvious shift of 0.7 eV to lower binding energy of both Pb 4f spectra is 10
observed. The characteristic peaks at 4f5/2 143.6 eV and 4f7/2 138.7 eV of lead ions 11 adsorbed on the composite are in good agreement with the reported values [47], and the 12
peak of Pb 4f7/2 shows a binding energy corresponding to the formation of Pb-O bond [48], 13 which indicates there occurred a special interaction between Pb2+ and TiO2. The Ti 2p and 14 O 1s XPS spectra of the composite material before and after adsorption are specifically 15
shown in Fig. 8c and d, respectively. Compared with the clean sample, a similar shift of 16
0.4 eV for both Ti 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 to low regions is observed. The Ti 2p2/3 binding energy 17 after adsorption becomes 458.5 eV from the original 458.9 eV before adsorption, and that 18
for Ti 2p1/2 changes from 464.7 eV to 464.3eV. The slight decrease in Ti 2p binding energy 19 after adsorption suggests strong interaction between Ti-O and Pb2+. The O 1s spectra can 20
be divided to four peaks concentrated at 533.4, 532.8, 531.2 and 530.3 eV, respectively, 21
among them the peaks of 533.4 and 532.8 eV correspond to the C-OH bond and C-O bond 1
of cellulose [49]. The change of area ratio of the peaks at 533.4 and 532.8 eV might be 2
caused by the adsorption of lead by the hydroxyl groups of cellulose. It has been reported 3
that the surface hydroxyl groups of TiO2 are the surface active sites [11], so the peaks 4 positioned at 531.2 and 530.3 eV could be assigned to OH and O2- groups of TiO2[50], 5 respectively. After adsorption, the area ratio of the peak at 531.2 eV for OH to the peak at 6 530.3 eV for O2- in the O 1s spectra decreases, which means that the OH groups on TiO2 7 surface have participated in the adsorption, allowing Pb2+ ions to mainly occupy the OH 8 surface sites of the mesoporous TiO2 [51]. Meanwhile, the increased ratio of O 2- after 9 adsorption further verifies the formation of Pb-O bond on the surface TiO2 [52]. In a 10 nutshell, the hydroxyl groups bonded to TiO2 are responsible for the adsorption of Pb 2+, 11 possibly forming the inner-sphere surface complex by electrostatic binding reactions [15, 12

sections.heading: 3.2.5 Regenerability 14
sections.text:
Good adsorption capacity and regenerability are important for continuous use of 15
absorbent material in practice. In order to evaluate the recycled performance of the 16 TiO2/CF composite, 0.2 M HCl was used as the regeneration reagent to desorb Pb 2+. The 17 desorbed composite was then used to adsorb Pb2+ again. The adsorption was conducted 18
using a solution volume of 60 mL and the volume of the regeneration solution was fixed 19
at 30 mL to maintain a volume ratio of 2:1. The adsorption-desorption cycles were 20
repeated, and the result is shown in Fig. 9. The regeneration efficiency of TiO2/CF 21
composites stays at 93% after 5 cycles, indicating a fair re-usability of the material due to 1
surface distribution of the mesoporous TiO2 on cellulose that exposes the many active 2 sites to enhance the adsorption and allow easy desorption of Pb2+. 3

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions 4
sections.text:
TiO2/CF nanocomposites were prepared by microwave-assisted hydrolysis of TiOSO4 5 in the presence of cellulose fibers. Mesoporous TiO2 particles with average size of 100 nm 6 were well-distributed on the surface of cellulose fibers. These particles are raspberry-like 7
agglomerates of 10 nm TiO2 primary nanoparticles. The particles are believed to bind to 8 the cellulose surface by the chemical interaction between the functional hydroxyl groups 9
of cellulose and the Ti crystal nucleus to form Ti-O bond. The resultant TiO2/CF 10 nanocomposites possessed mesoporous structure and high surface area, allowing fast 11 adsorption rate and good adsorption capacity for Pb2+ in simulated wastewater. The fitted 12
pseudo-second order adsorption kinetics indicated the existence of chemical bonding of 13 Pb2+ to TiO2, which was later confirmed by XPS analysis, proving the involvement of 14 hydroxyl groups of TiO2 in the adsorption process to form Pb-O bond. Adsorption on the 15 nanoengineered composites followed Freundlich isotherm and exhibited good 16
regeneration capacity, making practical use of the nanosorbents as an inexpensive green 17
technology possible for fast and efficient removal of heavy metals from polluted water. 18

Highlights 1 Microwave irradiation was applied to produce nano-TiO2/cellulose composite fibers 2 100 nm Raspberry-like TiO2 composed of 10 nm primary particles were formed 3 Composites fabricated by in situ TiO2 growth outperformed due to large surface area 4 Composites with hierarchical surface structure lead to rapid adsorption of Pb2+ 5 The adsorption was due to electrostatic interaction and the fibers were reusable 6
